ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A better understanding of USFP throughout history; the difference between national interest, strategy, and tactics; overview of major diplomatic successes and failures over the last 100 years of American history
I really enjoyed this class. I learned a lot about the theory, formation, and execution of American foreign policy.
I gained tools on how to approach evaluating American foreign policy decisions including breaking down issues into interests, strategies, and tactics on each side of foreign policy challenge.

I developed a much deeper understanding of the history of American foreign policy over the past one hundred years. In Ambassador Ford's class, I learned why American leaders decided to pursue the strategies they did on the most consequential issues of the 20th and 21st centuries, and what the impacts of those decisions were.
Conception of national interest vs. strategy vs. tactic. Significant discussion on what diplomacy actually looks like. Got to read books rather research papers unlike most classes.
I learned a lot about foreign policy history, and how to approach foreign policy questions from a very pragmatic and useful perspective.
I learnt about the history of foreign policy.
I learned a lot about foreign policy decisions in history.  I also learned a lot about how decision-making works and what questions should be asked when making decisions.
Learned to discern between national interest, strategy, and tactics. Also learned many lessons from debates on past U.S. foreign policy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: very well-thought out content, interesting readings (all novels); Professor Ford guides discussion; you actually receive meaningful feedback on assignments
Weaknesses: Professor Ford could have controlled the discussion a little bit more and encouraged quieter students to speak/louder students to speak less

The only thing I didn't love about this class is that the readings every week were very long, usually 150-200 pages. Professor Ford ran a very, very good seminar discussion and I learned a lot from class, from him, and from the readings I did. One other thing I didn't love was the assignments for the course. I don't really understand why we did lengthy foreign policy analysis... I think it would have made more sense to write policy analysis memos styled off of how they write memos at the State Department.

Ambassador Ford is very knowledgeable and uses his past experience to make the course more interesting.

Weakness: Sometimes the course felt as though we were just talking about the book or talking about history, rather than some of the more critical analyses of why something was a good or bad policy.
Strengths were definitely Ambassador Ford and his teaching style. He's really insightful and encouraging too.
This is an amazing class, and I have few recommendations for how it could be improved. Ambassador Ford is a great instructor who always moves the discussion in interesting directions.

Strengths: Prof. Ford is wonderful. Genuinely cares about the students and has a lot of experience and insights of his own.

Weaknesses: Discussion was more focused on major events / turning points in isolation. Sometimes lost track of the overall arc of US foreign policy history.
The readings were incredible and seminar discussions were also really good.
Ambassador Ford and the reading list are strengths.  He is incredibly knowledgable, sharp, and engaged in teaching the course.  Most of the books we read were great.  No weaknesses.
Strengths were the level of discussion and the expertise the professor brought as well as the readings assigned.

Professor Ford is a major strength of this class. He is excited about the topic, constantly engaged with students, and whip smart. Moreover, his selected readings are all fascinating and provide major insights into the turning points we focus on. Students were also super engaged with the material, so I looked forward to every class because of the energy that I knew would inevitably be there.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Just weekly Zoom seminar.
With the constraints imposed by COVID-19, the class went as well as it could.
Online seminars worked fine. No complaints there.

The course was as successful as it could be in a virtual setting, but obviously would have been better if it was in person. It is hard to have super organic conversations and using the "raise hand" function isn't the same as being able to look around the room and have a fluid conversation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're interested in historical FP, definitely. Professor Ford is excellent.
A really great class if you're interested in U.S. foreign policy. Professor Ford is amazing.

Absolutely. This was one of my favorite classes at Yale. If you get the chance to take it, definitely do. Be ready to put in the work, but it's well worth it. You'll learn a lot from Ambassador Ford and the other students in the seminar. Also, he's really invested in his students. During the pandemic, he even arranged to meet students in-person (safely and following the rules of course) and speak with us in-person and hear about our interests, background, career paths, etc. Definitely take it if you can get in.

I would certainly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in global history and the United States' place in the world. You will come out of this seminar with a much deeper appreciation for the challenges American leaders face in the world today.
Yes, especially if the particulars of diplomacy interest you.
Absolutely! Ambassador Ford has incredible insights and it was a privilege to learn from him.
Yes definitely.  Be prepared to actually do all the reading, but they are books you can mostly relax with and a nice break from hard academic reading for other classes.  Great course.  A must to take
Definitely, especially if you have any interest in U.S. foreign policy or want to learn about the continuity and trends in it.

Yes! Professor Ford is such an amazing professor to have. He is so engaged with the material and has such an interesting professional background that anyone can learn from. I looked forward to the class every week because students clearly wanted to be there and the books we read were so interesting. Be prepared though, the reading pace is about a book a week and you NEED to do it in order to be successful in the class.

comments: n/a
None.
All online seminar, but got to meet with Prof. Ford one-on-once during the semester
